There have been many attempts to ban [[football]], from the [[middle ages]] through to the modern day. The first such law was passed in [[England]] in 1314; it was followed by more than 30 in England alone between 1314 and 1667.<ref name="Women Football and Europe">{{cite book | isbn = 9781841262253 | title = Women, Football and Europe: Histories, Equity and Experience | editor1-last = Magee | editor1-first= Jonathan | year = 2007 | publisher = Meyer & Meyer Sport | editor2-last = Caudwell | editor2-first= Jayne | editor3-last = Liston | editor3-first= Kate | editor4-last = Scraton | editor4-first= Sheila | series = International Football Institute Series | volume = 1 | pages = }}</ref>{{rp|6}} Football faced armed opposition in the 18th Century when used as a cover for violent protest against the [[enclosure act]]. Women were banned from playing at English and Scottish Football League grounds in 1921, a ban that was only lifted in the 1970s. Female footballers still face similar problems in some parts of the world.
==Mass football in Europe== Mass or [[mob football]] was popular in [[Middle Ages|medieval]] and [[early modern Europe]]. It involved an unlimited number of players and very few rules; the game often caused damage to people and property and was seen as a distraction from more desirable work which led to many attempts at banning the game in Britain and France.
===England=== Complaints by London merchants led King [[Edward II of England]] to issue a proclamation banning football in London on 13 April 1314 because, "...there is great noise in the city caused by hustling over large balls from which many evils may arise which God forbid; we command and forbid, on behalf of the King, on pain of imprisonment, such game to be used in the city in the future."<ref name="Orejan">{{cite book |title=Football/Soccer: History and Tactics |last=Orejan |first=Jaime |year=2011 |publisher=McFarland & Company |location=USA |isbn=978-0-7864-4784-8 |page=18}}<!--|accessdate=18 August 2013 --></ref>
Playing football was seen as a distraction from practising [[archery]], which was a mandatory occupation<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/21h.416/www/militarytechnology/longbow.html |accessdate=18 August 2013 |title=Engineering the Medieval Achievement - The Longbow |author= Prof. Anne McCants |website=web.mit.edu |publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]}}</ref> for every Englishman for much of the Middle Ages because archers were so valuable in battle at that time. This led [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] and [[Edward IV of England|Edward IV]] of England to ban football in 1349 and 1477 respectively; the latter stated that, "No person shall practice...football and such games, but every strong and able bodied person shall practice with the bow for the reason that the national defence depends upon such bowmen." <ref name="Orejan" /> [[Richard II of England|Richard II]] also tried to outlaw the sport in 1389, as did [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]] in 1401.
Despite ordering the first known pair of [[football boots]], [[Henry VIII of England]] attempted a ban in 1540.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Henry VIII wore football boots |publisher=BBC NEWS Education | accessdate = 2014-02-22 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/3496589.stm }}</ref><ref>{{citation| page=5 |title=The Global Art of Soccer |author=Richard Witzig |publisher=CusiBoy Publishing |year=2006 |isbn=9780977668809 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H2T0ZD5S86QC&pg=PA5&dq=henry+ban+football+1540&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5iEIU4-pHeia0AXfpoDgCA&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=henry%20ban%20football%201540&f=false }}</ref><ref>{{citation |page=3 |title=Soccer: Rules, Tips, Strategy, and Safety |author=Brian Wingate |publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group |year=2007 |isbn=9781404209954 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=97jNT74E8DQC&pg=PA3&dq=henry+ban+football+1540&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5iEIU4-pHeia0AXfpoDgCA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=henry%20ban%20football%201540&f=false}}</ref> As with the other laws, this was only a partial success.{{Citation needed|reason=General cn, what did the people do? Is there any evidence of punishment for playing football? Were there mass protests or did it quietly start up again? Did participation even die down due to all these laws?|date=August 2013}}
By 1608, the local authorities in [[Manchester]] were complaining that: "With the ffotebale...[there] hath beene greate disorder in our towne of Manchester we are told, and glasse windowes broken yearlye and spoyled by a companie of lewd and disordered persons ..."<ref>[http://www.sport.gov.gr/2/24/243/2431/24314/243144/paper20.html International Olympic Academy (I.O.A.) (no date), “Minutes 7th International Post Graduate Seminar on Olympic Studies”] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080429135712/http://www.sport.gov.gr/2/24/243/2431/24314/243144/paper20.html |date=April 29, 2008 }}</ref> That same year, the word "football" was used disapprovingly by [[William Shakespeare]]. Shakespeare's play ''[[King Lear]]'' contains the line: "Nor tripped neither, you base football player" (Act I, Scene 4). Shakespeare also mentions the game in ''[[A Comedy of Errors]]'' (Act II, Scene 1):
{{quote|<poem>Am I so round with you as you with me, That like a football you do spurn me thus? You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither: If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.</poem>}}
"Spurn" literally means ''to kick away'', thus implying that the game involved kicking a ball between players.
King [[James I of England]]'s ''Book of Sports'' (1618) however, instructs Christians to play at football every Sunday afternoon after worship.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sHrejZJVc80C&pg=RA3-PA412&dq=football |title=John Lord Campbell, ''The Lives of the Lords Chancellors and Keepers of the Great Seal of England'', vol. 2, 1851, p. 412 |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-06-19|year=1851}}</ref> The book's aim appears to be an attempt to offset the strictness of the [[Puritans]] regarding the keeping of the [[Sabbath in Christianity|Sabbath]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reformed.org/books/hetherington/west_assembly/index.html?mainframe=/books/hetherington/west_assembly/chapter_1a.html#Book%20of%20Sports1618 |title=William Maxwell Hetherington, 1856, ''History of the Westminster Assembly of Divines, Ch.1 (Third Ed.) |publisher=Reformed.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}}</ref>
The [[Puritan]]s had some success in suppressing "disorderly" sports including football after the [[English Civil War]]. Players were fined or sentenced to public humiliation in the [[stocks]]. The Mayor of [[York]] fined 11 players 20 [[Shilling (English coin)|shillings]] each when their game resulted in a smashed church window in the winter of 1659-60. The prosecution triggered a violent protest and resulted in over 100 armed men breaking into the Mayor's house; the ringleader was later fined 10 [[Pound sterling|pounds]] or 400 shillings, a very large sum of money at the time.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/newsandevents/pressreleases/ne1000000086166/ |accessdate=18 August 2013 |date=17 December 2003 |title=Historian Reveals that Cromwellian Christmas Football Rebels Ran Riot |publisher=[[University of Warwick]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/1468/1468-h/1468-h.htm |last=Macaulay |first=Thomas Babington |authorlink=Thomas Babington Macaulay, 1st Baron Macaulay |title=The History of England from the Accession of James the Second |volume=1 |year=1848 |quote=[In 1685] the wages of the common agricultural labourer, from March to September, were fixed at...four shillings a week without food.}}</ref> Football became even more popular following the [[English Restoration|Restoration]] in 1660.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
The annual [[Scoring the Hales|Shrove Tuesday game]] was first played in 1762 in the streets of [[Alnwick]], and similar games were popular in many towns and villages at the time. The games were typically played in the streets which caused damage to property. A law was passed in 1818 banning street football. This law was ignored in Alnwick until 1827 when the [[Hugh Percy, 3rd Duke of Northumberland|Duke of Northumberland]] provided a field for the game to be played on legitimately.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.northumberlandgazette.co.uk/news/local-news/it-s-all-kicking-off-at-shrovetide-1-3136609 |title=It’s all kicking off at Shrovetide |date=4 March 2011 |publisher=[[Northumberland Gazette]] |accessdate=17 August 2013}}</ref>
===Scotland=== [[James I of Scotland]] decreed that ''Na man play at the fut ball,'' in the [[Football Act 1424|Football Act of 1424]];<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/history/the-game/opposition-to-the-game.html |accessdate=17 August 2013 |title=History of Football - Opposition to the Game |publisher=FIFA}}</ref> a further act of parliament was passed under the rule of [[James II of Scotland|James II]] in 1457 which banned both football and golf.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://digital.nls.uk/golf-in-scotland/banned/1457-act.html |accessdate=17 August 2013 |title=Acts of Parliament banning golf |publisher=[[National Library of Scotland]] }}</ref>
===France=== The French game [[La soule]] is another mass participation ball game similar to the English and Scottish mob football. It was banned by [[Philip V of France|Phillippe V]] in 1319, and again by [[Charles V of France|Charles V]] in 1369.
In 1440 the [[bishop of Tréguier]] threatened players with excommunication and a fine of 100 [[French sol|sol]], saying that "these dangerous and pernicious games must be prohibited because of hatred, grudges and enmities which, under the veil of recreational fun, accumulate in many hearts".<ref>{{cite journal |pages=576–7 |language=French |title=La soûle en Bretagne et les jeux similaires du Cornwall et du Pays de Galles |trans-title=La soule in Brittany and similar games in Cornwall and Wales |author=L. Gougaud |journal=Annales de Bretagne |year=1911 |volume=27-4 |url=http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/abpo_0003-391x_1911_num_27_4_1374?_Prescripts_Search_tabs1=standard& }}</ref>
==Enclosure Acts== The [[Inclosure Acts|Enclosure Acts]] placed common land into individual ownership and removed the rights of local people to use the land as they had previously. Football was used as a means to protest this enclosure, and the supposed football game was often a pretext to organise a riot. One such event in Deeping Level, north of [[Peterborough]], led to the sherriff of Lincolnshire raising the [[Posse comitatus (common law)|posse comitatus]] to quell the riots.<ref>{{cite thesis |type=Ph.D. |first=Heather |last=Falvey |title=Custom, resistance and politics: Local experiences of improvement in early modern England |chapter=Rioting under the guise of football |year=2007 |page=356 |url=http://wrap.warwick.ac.uk/1143/2/WRAP_THESIS_Falvay2_2007.pdf |accessdate=17 August 2013}}</ref> In 1740, "a match of futtball was cried at Kettering, of 500 men a side, but the design was to, "Pull Down Lady Betey Jesmaine's Mill's." In 1764, {{convert|2000|acre|km2}} of land was enclosed at [[West Haddon]], Northamptonshire. A game of football was advertised in a local newspaper<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.northamptonshiretimeline.com/scene/1765-mercury-reports-enclosure-protest/#glossary-48 |accessdate=17 August 2013 |title=1765AD Northampton Mercury Reports Protest Against Enclosures |website=Northamptonshire Timeline}}</ref> and after the kick off the mob set about tearing down and burning the fences amounting to £1,500 worth of damage.<ref>{{cite book |last=McArdle |first=David |title=Football, Society and the Law |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5bdgnlZV-FgC&pg=PA2&lpg=PA2#v=onepage |accessdate=17 August 2013 |year=2000 |publisher=[[Cavendish Publishing]] |isbn=1 85941 437 0 |page=10}}</ref>
==Street football== The British [[Highway Act 1835|Highway Act]] of 1835 banned the playing of [[football]] on public highways,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/originsofrugby.htm|title=Origins of Rugby|work=Rugby Football History|accessdate=14 April 2010|quote="football for the common man was being suppressed, notably by the 1835 highways act which forbade the playing of football on highways and public land - which is where most games took place"}}</ref> and gave a maximum penalty of forty shillings to anyone who "shall play at Football or any other Game on any Part of the said Highways, to the Annoyance of any Passenger or Passengers."<ref>[[#opsi1835|The Highway Act 1835]], section 72</ref>
==Women's football== English [[Women's football (soccer)|women's football]] matches began in 1895 but following the first international match in 1920, women were banned from all affiliated FA grounds from 1921-71 on the grounds that, "the game of football is quite unsuitable for females and ought not to be encouraged."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23147072 |title=Women's Euros 2013: Women's football's forgotten heroines |accessdate=17 August 2013 |last=Croydon |first=Emily |date=7 July 2013 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |location=UK}}</ref> The [[Scottish Football Association]] did not formally recognise women's football until 1973 after pressure from [[UEFA]].<ref name="Women Football and Europe" />{{rp|17}}
In 1931 the women's team from [[IF Fløya|Fløya]] in [[Tromsø]] wrote to the [[Norwegian Football Association]] seeking permission to stage a series of fundraising matches. They played the first match before receiving a response: "Ladies should not play football... the ladies could also get injuries that destroyed their reproductive organs. Fløya should therefore not allow or let ladies enter the football field." Further fundraising matches had to be abandoned. Women continued to play football in Norway despite the lack of official recognition, and were accepted into the Norwegian FA in 1976.<ref name="Women Football and Europe" />{{rp|43–48}}
The [[Iran women's national football team|Iran women's football team]] forfeited an [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics - Women's tournament|Olympic]] qualifying match because the team's [[Islam in association football#Islamic dress code and football|dress code]] mandated wearing of the [[Hijab by country#Iran|maghnaeh]] to cover their heads. FIFA ruled that the kit broke one of their rules and did not let Iran participate, which meant [[Jordan women's national football team|Jordan]] were awarded a 3-0 result for the forfeit.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-06-06/sports/35234557_1_iranian-women-headscarves-press-tv |title=Olympics 2012: FIFA bans headscarves for Iranian women’s soccer team |accessdate=18 August 2013 |last=Erdbrink |first=Thomas |date=6 June 2011 |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |location=USA}}</ref> In July 2013 Libya's women's football team was banned from playing in an international tournament in Berlin, despite initially being given permission to attend. The Libyan Football Association gave concerns about the need for fasting during Ramadan as the reason for this ban.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/19/libya-womens-football-team-banned-ramadan |title=Libya's women's football team banned from major tournament |accessdate=17 August 2013 |last=Stephen |first=Chris |date=19 July 2013 |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK}}</ref>

'''CRS Robotics''' Corporation (currently operating as [[Thermo CRS|Thermo CRS Limited]]) was a robotics company based out of [[Burlington, Ontario|Burlington]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]. CRS Robotics designed, manufactured, distributed, and serviced human scale articulated robots [[Articulated robot]] and laboratory automation systems. Human scale robots have approximately the same reach, speed, the range of motion, the degree of articulation and lifting capacity as a human being and are designed specifically to perform tasks that are hazardous, highly repetitive or generally unsuited for humans. [[Laboratory Automation]] applications are used to speed the effort of drug discovery for pharmaceutical and biotechnology customers.
CRS Robotics was notable in the field of automated lab systems due to their developments in high throughput and ultra high throughput automated systems. Among other things, these developments included their advanced scheduling software, called [[POLARA]], which was an open and extensible platform for the management and control of complex automated systems. As an example, a "good portion of the work" for "the preliminary map of the human genetic code was performed on CRS Automated Lab Systems".<ref>[http://www.roboticsonline.com/public/articles/archivedetails.cfm?id=192 Canadian Company Plays Key Role in Human Genome Project - Robotics Online<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The company commenced operations in 1982 as an engineering firm providing consulting services to Canadian machine tool manufacturers in the area of machine controls. The company sold its first robot, the M1 small robot system, in 1985. The company shipped its first [[laboratory automation]] system in 1997.
The company changed its name to CRS Robotics Corporation in 1994. In 1995, the company completed an initial public offering. The company was listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
In May 2002, the company was acquired 100% by the [[Thermo Electron|Thermo Electron Corporation]],<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/thermo-electron-acquiring-crs-robotics/article18286986/ Thermo Electron acquiring CRS Robotics]</ref> ([[New York Stock Exchange|NYSE]]: [https://www.nyse.com/about/listed/lcddata.html?ticker=TMO TMO]), and its name was subsequently changed to [[Thermo CRS]]. After the acquisition, the company still continues to develop laboratory automation systems.
==List of CRS Robots== *M1 (five axis articulated robot) *A255 (five axis articulated robot) *A465 (six axis articulated robot) *F3 (six axis articulated robot) *Catalyst 3 (three axis articulated robot) *Catalyst 5 (five axis articulated robot) *Dimension4 Family of Robots **VAL (Vertical Array Loader) (four axis robot) **Flip Mover (1, 2 or 3 axis versions) **LPT (Linear Plate Transport) (1 axis)

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=April 2016}} {{original research|date=March 2016}} }}
[[File:Camera Eats First Examples.jpg|thumb|Photo examples of the "Camera Eats First"]]
'''‘Camera Eats First’''' is the behavior and global phenomenon of people taking photos of their meals with digital or smartphone cameras before they eat, mostly followed by uploading the photos to the [[social media]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theinkslingerstulc.weebly.com/features/3-reasons-you-should-take-food-picture-before-eat|title=Take Food Picture Before Eating Becomes a Trend|last=Lee|first=Jie Yin|date=1 October 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=4 April 2016}}</ref> The term refers to how people feed their cameras first by taking photos of their food before feeding themselves.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skypost.hk/%E6%B8%AF%E8%81%9E/%E5%9F%8E%E5%B8%82%E7%86%B1%E8%A9%B1/20150714/001/%E9%A3%AF%E8%81%9A%E7%9B%B8%E6%A9%9F%E9%A3%9F%E5%85%88%20%E6%9C%8B%E5%8F%8B%E9%A4%93%E5%A3%9E%E7%84%A1%E7%99%AE/184195|title=飯聚相機食先 朋友餓壞無癮 心理學家:藉分享動態 獲取關注|last=|first=|date=14 July 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=9 April 2016}}</ref> It derives from professional [[food photography]] while the behavior of the ‘Camera Eats First’ is generally for personal use such as keeping photographic food diaries<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/07/dining/07camera.html|title=First Camera, Then Fork|last=Murphy|first=Kate|date=6 April 2010|website=|publisher=|access-date=9 April 2016}}</ref> instead of commercial purposes. It can also be referred as online food photography, [[food porn]] and photogenic food.[https://www.instagram.com/wingthefoodie/]
== Background == [[File:Camera eat first 1.jpg|thumb|Food photos posted by users from Instagram]] [[File:Camera eats first 2.jpg|thumb|Food photos posted by users from instagram]]One reason for the rise of ‘Camera Eats First’ is the rise of digital convenience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dcfever.com/column/read.php?id=3101|title=相機食先—簡易食物拍法|last=Chan|first=Ivan|date=1 May 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=9 April 2016}}</ref> The global participation in social media is on continual surge with the advancement in technology and commonness of digital devices that serve as mediums for social media. The veteran food photographer of [[The New York Times]], [[The Wall Street Journal]] and [[Saveur]] magazine Dave Hagerman mentioned that [[Instagram]], contains the most examples of ‘Camera Eats First’ photos. This platform provides a way for people to share and indulge in their common obsession of food globally, thus encouraging taking pictures of food for personal use.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/kuala-lumpur/restaurants/camera-eats-first-is-instagram-changing-the-way-we-eat|title=Camera eats first: Is Instagram changing the way we eat?|last=Koh|first=Joyce|date=22 December 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> More importantly, keeping a photogenic food diary is being treated as a form of self representation, showing who they are from what they eat in accordance to the quote of “Tell me what you eat, and I will tell you what you are,” by the French philosopher and gourmand [[Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin]], 1825.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/07/dining/07camera.html?_r=1|title=First Camera, Then Fork|last=Murphy|first=Kate|date=6 April 2010|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref>
== Prevalence == [[File:Camera Eats First 3.jpg|thumb|A post about food using "#foodie" on Twitter]] The 'Camera Eats First' phenomenon is becoming more common all over the world with the emergence of smartphone and social media. After taking photos of their food, people will usually share the photos on social media such as [https://www.instagram.com/wingthefoodie/ Instagram], [https://www.ecpi.edu/blog/16-facebook-pages-every-culinary-arts-food-lover-should-follow Facebook], [https://www.ecpi.edu/blog/16-facebook-pages-every-culinary-arts-food-lover-should-follow Twitter] and [https://www.pinterest.com/categories/food_drink/ Pinterest]. According to [https://web.stagram.com/?locale=en Webstagram], there are more than 180 million photos with the hashtag #food currently on Instagram.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://websta.me/hot|title=TOP 100 TAGS|last=|first=|date=|website=WEBSTA|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> Other hashtags such as [[Food porn|#foodporn]] and [[foodie|#foodie]] are often added to these photos.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hashtags.org/featured/5-top-food-hashtags-and-why-they-work/|title=5 Top Food Hashtags and Why They Work.|last=|first=|date=9 July 2013|website=Hashtag.org|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> It is estimated that 90 new photos hash-tagged #foodporn are uploaded to Instagram every minute.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.menulog.com.au/blog/social-media-changing-eat/|title=How Social Media Is Changing The Way We Eat|last=|first=|date=3 September 2014|website=Menulog|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> The phenomenon is especially more prevalent among the younger generation. According to a survey done by [[News Corp Australia|News Limited]], “54 per cent of 18-24 year olds have taken a photo of their food while eating out, while 39 per cent have posted it somewhere online. This compares with only 5 per cent of over-50s who say they share food snaps on forums such as Facebook and Twitter.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/food/aussies-share-the-food-love-by-posting-pictures-of-meals-on-social-media/story-fneuz8wn-1226637885462|title=Aussies share the food love by posting pictures of meals on social media|last=Wilkinson|first=Simon|date=9 May 2013|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref>
== Positive Effects ==
=== Increased connection and satisfying psychological needs === Through sharing food photos on social media, users can form connections with other people and strengthen interpersonal bonds. Food is always a community event and a bonding experience which can bridge the gap between people and share joy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/culture/what-does-instagramming-our-food-say-about-modern-eaters.html|title=What does Instagramming our food say about modern eaters?|last=Heimbuch|first=Jaymi|date=6 June 2013|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> Thus, sharing food photos also acts as a "social glue" to gather people together to participate in each other's eating experiences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://greatist.com/happiness/social-media-food-050813|title=How Social Media Changes The Way We Think About Food|last=Lebowitz|first=Shana|date=8 May 2013|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> Through the sharing, a private dining experience is turned into a communal bonding activity. People can communicate and share their emotions with others, for example, happiness in a party.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.austin360.com/news/lifestyles/food-cooking/austin360eats-how-instagram-social-media-food-phot/nc9xy/|title=How Instagram, social media food photography have changed how we eat|last=Broyles|first=Addie|date=6 February 2014|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> In addition, people can satisfy the psychological needs of “belongingness and love” and “esteem” according to the [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://snipandsharemonkey.tumblr.com/post/129781442196/camera-eats-first|title=CAMERA EATS FIRST|last=Lai|first=Justin|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> as they can share their experiences and show off to the world what they are eating.
=== Business opportunities === Sharing food photos can facilitate people’s obsession with food, but it can also help promote restaurants. Sharing of food photo can be a visual pull that will subconsciously alert people to check out new restaurants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/kuala-lumpur/restaurants/camera-eats-first-is-instagram-changing-the-way-we-eat|title=Camera eats first: Is Instagram changing the way we eat?|last=Koh|first=Joyce|date=22 December 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> [[Carmel Winery]], a restaurant in Israel, gained $400,000 from free promotion by food photos on social media and successfully boosted its sales by 13% owing to the help of “Camera Eats First”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theforkmanager.com/blog/add-instagram-to-your-restaurants-marketing-strategy-and-entice-your-customers/|title=Add Instagram to Your Restaurant’s Marketing Strategy And Entice Your Customers!|last=|first=|date=7 December 2015|website=Thefork Manager A Company Tripadvisor.|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> On the other hand, some chefs in Hong Kong would take "food porn" photos and post them on social media because they thought that the "Camera Eats First" phenomenon served as a channel for them to collect feedback from customers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/food-wine/article/1441916/taking-food-porn-photos-hong-kong-so-popular-even-chefs-are|title=Taking 'food porn' photos in Hong Kong is so popular even the chefs are doing it|first=Mischa|publisher=|last1=Moselle|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref> which is a vital information for them to make improvements to their dishes.
=== Making food taste better === According to a study mentioned on Bit of News,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bitofnews.com/instagramming-your-food-actually-makes-it-taste-better-study-says/|title=Instagramming your food actually makes it taste better, study says|last=Xiao|first=Xu|date=13 March 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> taking photos of pleasurable food, such as cakes, before eating it can increase the savoring — "the increased anticipation built up from taking photos of the food made it taste better." If people don't take a photo, they may even feel something is missing from the savoring experience.
== Negative Effects ==
=== Infringement of chefs' intellectual property === The 'Camera Eats First' behavior was banned in some French restaurants, as diners may infringe upon chefs' [[intellectual property]]. Some French chefs criticized that this behavior would ruin the surprise of future diners, as they might have seen the photos of dishes shared on the internet before coming to the restaurant. Diners posting the photos on social media may give rise to intellectual property disputes about other chefs copying the ideas and presentation of the plates, which are the creative elements contributed by the original chefs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2560940/Stop-taking-food-snaps-plead-chefs-French-restaurant-bans-cameras-head-cook-complained-diners-taking-pictures-meals.html|title=Stop taking food snaps, plead chefs: French restaurant bans cameras after head cook complained about diners taking pictures of their meals|first=Louise|publisher=|last1=Eccles|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref>
=== Impoliteness and worsening relationships === The "Camera Eats First" behavior may be considered as an impolite table manner. When diners photograph the food, they may place too much emphasis on the appearance of the food and try to capture the food at its best angle by rearranging tables. It may disrupt other people dining and spoil the enjoyment of their meal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2560940/Stop-taking-food-snaps-plead-chefs-French-restaurant-bans-cameras-head-cook-complained-diners-taking-pictures-meals.html|title=Stop taking food snaps, plead chefs: French restaurant bans cameras after head cook complained about diners taking pictures of their meals|last=Eccles|first=Louise|date=17 February 2014|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> They may also leave their partners in a state of hunger and impatience.
On the other hand, while people are busy photographing their food and sharing it online, they will have less time to communicate with their friends and family. One of the functions of [[eating]]—enabling families and friends to gather together and enhance intimacy—is lost.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/culture/what-does-instagramming-our-food-say-about-modern-eaters.html|title=What does Instagramming our food say about modern eaters?|last=Heimbuch|first=Jaymi|date=6 June 2013|website=|publisher=|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> The 'Camera Eats First" behavior may result in worsening relationships and weakening connection with others in contrast with the positive effect mentioned.

'''The Center for Telehealth & E-Health Law''' ('''CTeL'''), established in 1995 by a consortium including the [[Mayo Foundation]], [[Cleveland Clinic Foundation]], [[Texas Children's Hospital]], and the Mid-West Rural Telemedicine Consortium, is a non-profit organization committed to overcoming legal and regulatory barriers to the utilization of [[telehealth]] and related [[e-health]] services.<ref>[http://www.telehealthlawcenter.org/content/?page=9 Center for Telehealth and e-Health Law<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218120146/http://www.telehealthlawcenter.org/content/?page=9 |date=December 18, 2008 }}</ref> CTeL, based in Washington, D.C., specializes in compiling, analyzing and disseminating information on legal and regulatory issues information associated with telemedicine. It also handles underlying issues such as licensure and reimbursement.
CTeL briefs public policymakers, writes reports, and provides testimony in support of telehealth. In its materials, CTeL argues that expanding the use of telehealth can improve patient safety, reduce medical errors, and increase patient access to primary and specialty care in both rural and urban settings. CTeL offers a variety of services, including involvement in public policy. CTeL activities include:
* "Telehealth Leadership Conference" – annual conference dedicated solely to telehealth issues and telehealth advocacy. * Telehealth Policy Clerkship Program – offered for second and third year law students interested in public policy and legal issues as they apply to advancing communication technologies in the practice of medicine. * Washington Live! Brown Bag Lunches in Washington, D.C. – monthly seminars on various topics of interest in telehealth and e-health. * *The National Telehealth Resource Center (NTRC), one of several telehealth resource centers funded through a grant from the Office for the Advancement of Telehealth at the [[Health Resources and Services Administration]] (HRSA) in the Department of Health and Human Services.<ref>[http://www.hrsa.gov/telehealth/granteedirectory/overview.htm HRSA - Telehealth Grantee Directory<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104133905/http://www.hrsa.gov/telehealth/granteedirectory/overview.htm |date=January 4, 2008 }}</ref> * In 2004, CTeL worked with HRSA's Office for the Advancement of Telehealth (OAT) and the [[University of Colorado Health Sciences Center]] to perform an analysis of the use of telehealth in skilled nursing facilities for a report to Congress. This report is titled "Multi-State Telehealth Practice" and summarizes the current state of physician and nurse licensure issues. * Also in 2004, CTeL was recognized by the [[United States Department of Commerce]]: "[The] progress there has been in resolving such issues can be attributed to a very recent and concentrated effort by such stakeholders as... Center for Telemedicine Law, and the Office for the Advancement of Telehealth (OAT), within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)." – Innovation, Demand, & Investment in Telehealth, US Commerce Department, Feb. 2004.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080513143129/http://www.telehealthlawcenter.org/ CTeL] * [http://www.hrsa.gov/telehealth// Office for the Advancement of Telehealth]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox academic |image= |birth_date=6 August 1957 [[Leicester]] |alma_mater=[[University of Hull]]
[[University of Aberdeen]] |discipline=[[Medical Physics]] |website={{url|http://staff.qut.edu.au/staff/langtonc/}} }} '''Christian Langton''' (born 6 August 1957) is a British researcher in [[medical physics]]. He is Adjunct Professor of Medical Physics, [[Queensland University of Technology]], [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]].{{Cite web |url=http://staff.qut.edu.au/staff/langtonc/ |title=Professor Christian Langton |publisher=[[Queensland University of Technology]] |access-date=2018-03-28}} ==Professional life== Langton is notable for his development of an early detection system for osteoporosis using ultrasonic waves.{{cite news|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,,1812460,00.html |title=100 UK university discoveries |publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date= 5 July 2006|accessdate=28 May 2011 |location=London}} ==Honours and awards== Langton was awarded a [[Doctor of Science]] (DSc) in Medical Physics from the [[University of Hull]] (the first to be awarded in a decade) for his work on the measurement of broadband ultrasonic attenuation in cancellous bone. In 2015 he received an Honorary Doctorate from the [[University of Eastern Finland]]. In 2006 Langton's work was listed by EurekaUK as one of the top 100 UK university discoveries to come out of the UK in the past 50 years. In 2008, the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Department_of_Health_and_Social_Care UK Department of Health] recognised Langton in a publication highlighting eleven projects that had contributed to ‘60 years of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Health_Service NHS] research benefiting patients’. His work is listed under the 'Hull Firsts' at the Carnegie Heritage Centre in Kingston-upon-Hull https://www.carnegiehull.co.uk/hull-firsts/index.php ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Langton, Christian}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:People from Brisbane]] [[Category:Queensland University of Technology faculty]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Hull]] [[Category:Ultrasonographers]] [[Category:Medical physicists]] [[Category:Living people]]

'''Clinical Associates''' are a category of [[health professional]] found in [[South Africa]]. They assess patients, make diagnoses, prescribe treatment and perform minor surgery under the supervision of a [[physician]].
Registration with the Medical and Dentists Board requires a Bachelor of Clinical Medical Practice degree <ref>Health Professions Council of South Africa: ''Professional boards - Medical & Dental (and Medical Science)'' - http://www.hpcsa.co.za/board_meddent.php, accessed 15 March 2011.</ref> - a three-year program offered at the [[Walter Sisulu University]] since January 2008<ref>''Speech by Minister Manto Tshabalala-Msimang at the official launch of the Clinical Associate Programme in South Africa, Umthata'', 18 August 2008 - http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2008/08082012451006.htm</ref> and now also offered at the [[University of Witwatersrand]], [[University of Pretoria]] and the [[University of Limpopo]] (Medunsa Campus).<ref>SouthAfrica.info: ''Mid-level health professionals for South Africa'' - http://www.southafrica.info/about/health/clinical-associates.htm, accessed 15 March 2011.</ref><ref>University of the Witwatersrand: ''Clinical Associates - Bachelor of Clinical Medical Practice'' - http://web.wits.ac.za/Academic/Health/Entities/RuralHealth/Clinical+Associates.htm, accessed 15 March 2011.</ref>
Similar health workers are called [[clinical officer]]s in other parts of Africa, [[physician assistant]]s in the US and [[feldsher]]s in parts of the former Soviet Union - all grouped under “paramedical practitioners” in the [[International Standard Classification of Occupations]], 2008 revision.<ref>World Health Organization: ''Classifying health workers''. Geneva, WHO, 2010.</ref>
==See also== *[[Health care provider]]s *[[Allied health professions]] *[[Clinical officer]]s *[[Assistant Medical Officer]]s *[[Health Extension Officer]]s *[[Bachelor of Clinical Medicine and Community Health]] *[[Bachelor of Clinical Medical Practice]]
